   ASSESSMENT:  60 yoM with history of ESRD and renal stones presenting
   with abdominal pain, found to have left pylonephritis and high
   suspecion for renal and prostate abscesses.
   PLAN:
   # Pylonephritis/renal and prostatic abscesses: Pt may have seeded
   urinary tract during recent urologic procedures. Possible causative
   organisms would include urinary flora (E. Coli, enterococcus, staph)
   versus MRSA given indwelling stent.  Patient went for IR drainage
   yesterday which resulted in 4cc bloody fluid from perinephric site and
   5cc pus like fluid from prostatic site.  There is some concern that the
   needle went through the prostate and drained the bladder.  Called by
   OSH for +BC
 GNR in
 bottles.  Lactate decreased with fluids and
   blood pressure responeded to fluids.
   - continue emperic broad coverage with Zosyn and vancomycin.  Add one
   dose of Gentamycin to double cover GNR.
   - follow-up blood and urinary cultures
   - hold all antihypertensives for now
   - pyridium and narcotics for pain control
   # ESRD: MWF schedule as above. Will notify renal of pt's presence so HD
   may continue.  Will hold ACEi for now as above.  Continue renagel.
   -HD today.
   # HTN: Hold antihypertensives for now given tenuous clinical status.

   given planned surgery.
   # Coagulopathy: INR 1.5 on admission. No prior history of liver

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal stones. He presented with abdominal pain and was found to have left pyelonephritis and a high suspicion for renal and prostate abscesses. The patient underwent interventional radiology (IR) drainage, which resulted in the drainage of bloody fluid from the perinephric site and pus-like fluid from the prostatic site. There is concern that the needle may have drained the bladder instead of the prostate. The patient is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics (Zosyn and vancomycin) and has been given one dose of gentamicin for double coverage against gram-negative rods (GNR) sepsis, as recommended by the urology team.

Medical Complications:
1. GNR Sepsis: The patient has a positive blood culture for GNR bacteria, indicating a systemic infection. The addition of gentamicin is intended to provide double coverage against GNR organisms.
2. Possible Prostatitis: The patient's prostatic massage revealed tenderness and boggy consistency, suggesting prostatitis. The drainage procedure may have caused trauma to the prostate, leading to this condition.
3. Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, indicating anemia. Further evaluation and management are necessary.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's INR is elevated at 1.4

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal stones presenting with abdominal pain. He was found to have left pyelonephritis and a high suspicion for renal and prostate abscesses. The patient underwent interventional radiology (IR) drainage yesterday, resulting in the removal of bloody fluid from the perinephric site and pus-like fluid from the prostatic site. There is concern that the needle may have inadvertently drained the bladder instead of the prostate. The patient's blood pressure has been low, requiring fluid boluses and maintenance fluids. His potassium level initially increased but improved after fluids, and his lactate level is within normal range. The patient is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) and vancomycin, with the addition of gentamicin for double coverage against Gram-negative bacteria. Blood and urinary cultures have been ordered, and the patient is scheduled for hemodialysis today. His other medical conditions include hypertension and anemia, for which he is being closely monitored. The patient's code status is full code, and he is currently admitted to the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's presentation suggests a possible severe infection, which could progress to sepsis if not effectively managed.
2. Organ abscesses: Given the suspicion of renal and prostate abscesses, these may require further

   MICU Attending Addendum:
   On this day I examined the patient and was present for the key portions
   of the services provided.  I have reviewed Dr [**First Name (STitle) 5725**]
s note and I agree
   with the findings and plan of care.  Mr [**Known lastname 5708**] was admitted with
   urosepsis, including hypotension and positive blood cultures.  Today he
   is doing much better.  His blood pressure, while not his norm, is
   certainly adequate for perfusion and has only  needed fluids, not
   pressors. Lactate much improved. He also feels better and even is
   demanding to eat! We will give double GNR coverage for a couple more
   days, but I think his Vancomycin can be stopped, as no evidence of a
   GPC infection. He should remain in MICU for at least another day, but
   hopefully soon thereafter he will be stable enough for transfer to the
   wards with urology f/u.  35 min spent in the care of this critically
   ill patient.
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 548**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 549**], MD

The patient underwent interventional radiology (IR) drainage yesterday, which resulted in the removal of bloody fluid from the perinephric site and pus-like fluid from the prostatic site. There is concern that the needle may have drained the bladder instead of the prostate. Additionally, one dose of gentamicin was added to double cover gram-negative bacteria (GNR) sepsis, considering the possibility of prostatitis.

TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: prostatic abscess s/p drainage
   24 Hour Events:
   - hemodialysis- no fluid removed
   - micro data- GNR in urine, prostatic abscess fluid, and [**2-11**] bcx; (from
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 13**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] Hospital [**6-8**]: Pseudomonas aeroginosa 2/2 blood cultures,
   no sensitivities yet)
   - stopped vancomycin, continued Zosyn and gentamicin
   - urology recs- keep stent in, to be removed by outpatient urologist
   once infection clears in [**3-15**] weeks; keep foley to gravity until
   discharge, once afebrile and no leukocytosis; start flomax and proscar;
   continue antibiotics for 4-6 weeks for prostatitis; ADAT
   - renal recs- increase Zosyn to 2.25g IV q8h; dose gent by level, stop
   maintanence fluids
   - access- PIV x3
   - goal I+O- slightly positive overnight
   - CXR- probable subsegmental atelectasis or scarring at the left base.
   Consider followup imaging to exclude progression to infiltrate, if
   clinically indicated. No CHF. Right IJ line tip, as described. No ptx.
   - re: kidney transplant, brother [**Name (NI) 5742**] is ill on [**Hospital Ward Name 1107**] in MICU
   (GIB, cirrhosis) and has offered to donate his kidney to [**Known firstname **] should
   he die; however, it appears from recent update that brother is to be
   extubated and is actually doing better; [**Known firstname **] is followed by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 5743**] in [**Location (un) 3198**] (nephrologist) and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5744**] at [**Hospital 839**] Hospital
   in NH (transplant surgeon); **note that [**Known firstname **] and brother do not get
   along--brother has EtOH history, etc--and it appears that [**Known firstname **] is
   not aware of this plan for kidney transplant, nor is it apparent that
   he would agree to it. The family ([**Known firstname 5745**] sister and [**Name2 (NI) 5746**]
   daughter) are trying to arrange this**
   - overnight- no significant events
   - this morning complain of persistant suprapubic pain, but improved
   from yesterday

   abdominal pain, found to have left pylonephritis and high suspecion for

   # Pylonephritis/renal and prostatic abscesses: now s/p IR drainage [**6-9**]
   which resulted in 4 cc bloody fluid from perinephric site and 5 cc pus
   like fluid from prostatic site. OSH blood cultures are growing
   Pseudomonas in [**3-13**] culture bottles, sensitivities pending. So far

   -continue empiric broad coverage with Zosyn

The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal stones who presented with abdominal pain. He was found to have left pyelonephritis and a high suspicion for renal and prostate abscesses. The patient underwent image-guided drainage of the abscesses, resulting in the removal of 4 cc bloody fluid from the perinephric site and 5 cc pus-like fluid from the prostatic site.

His blood cultures are growing Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and he has been receiving vancomycin and gentamicin. Currently, he is on piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) for empiric coverage of Pseudomonas.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.9°C (100.3°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 126/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. His blood glucose level is 84 mg/dL, white blood cell count is 18.1 K/uL, hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL, platelet count is 141 K/uL, creatinine is 7.8 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen is 103 mg/dL.

- The patient is a 60-year-old man with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal stones.
- He presented with abdominal pain and was found to have left pyelonephritis and suspected renal and prostate abscesses.
- The patient underwent interventional radiology (IR) drainage, resulting in the removal of bloody fluid from the perinephric site and pus-like fluid from the prostatic site.
- Blood cultures are growing Pseudomonas, and antibiotic sensitivities are pending.
- The patient has been started on Zosyn for empirical coverage against Pseudomonas.
- He is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics, and the plan is to continue this until follow-up blood culture sensitivities are available.
- The patient will be held on all antihypertensives for now, and pain control will be managed with Pyridium and narcotics.
- Tamsulosin and finasteride have been prescribed by the urology team.
- The patient will require a 5-week antibiotic course, after which the stent can be removed.
- For ESRD management, the patient will continue on a MWF schedule as previously planned, with ongoing HD and Renagel.
- Antihypertensives will be restarted when the patient's blood pressure allows.
- Anemia is likely due to ESRD and

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal stones.
- He presented with abdominal pain and was found to have left pyelonephritis and a suspected renal and prostate abscess.
- The patient underwent interventional radiology drainage, resulting in the removal of bloody fluid from the perinephric site and pus-like fluid from the prostatic site.
- Blood cultures are growing Pseudomonas, and the patient has been started on empiric broad coverage with Zosyn.
- The plan is to continue this antibiotic and follow up with blood culture sensitivities to adjust antibiotics accordingly.
- All antihypertensives have been held, and pain control will be managed with Pyridium and narcotics.
- Tamsulosin and finasteride have been prescribed per urology, and a 5-week antibiotic course is planned for the patient, with stent removal after clearing the infection.
- The patient's ESRD treatment schedule remains unchanged on MWF.
- Renal dosing for hemodialysis will continue, and Renagel will be continued.
- Antihypertensives will be restarted when the patient's blood pressure allows, and lisinopril and amlodipine will be the medications of choice.
- Anemia management is pending iron studies and reticulocyte count, and an active type and screen is ordered.
- The patient
